title: Why Your Dog Might Think You’re a Bonehead
intro: The verdict is in: female dogs actively evaluate human competence.

transcript.author: Karen Hopkin
transcript.text: This is Scientific American’s 60-Second Science. I’m Karen Hopkin. Ever get the feeling that your cat is judging you?  [Cat meows]

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Well, you’re in for a surprise. Because it’s actually your pooch who might be viewing you with a critical eye. [Dog barking in experiment]

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: That’s according to a study that shows that dogs can assess human aptitude…and will look toward people who seem to know what they’re doing. The work appears in the journal Behavioral Processes.

transcript.author: Hitomi Chijiiwa
transcript.text: Our aim was to test whether dogs are sensitive to humans’ competence levels. And whether they evaluate humans on this trait.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Hitomi Chijiiwa is an assistant professor at Osaka University. If critiquing people’s proficiency seems an odd job for a pup, it may not be all that far fetched. Canines have spent more than 10,000 years by our sides.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: [So] Dogs are highly sensitive to human behavior.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: And they pay particular attention to things like how cooperative we are.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: For example, our previous study showed that dogs avoid people who refuse to help their owner.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: So Chijiiwa and her colleagues got to wondering whether dogs might also rate us in terms of our skillfulness. Particularly if those skills might come in handy for our four-footed little friends. So they set up a simple experiment.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: We showed 60 dogs two persons manipulating transparent containers. One person is competent.

transcript.author: Hopkin:
transcript.text: That person was able to pop open the top after just a couple of twists. [Sound from experiment]

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: Whereas the other person is incompetent and they failed at this task.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: That person tried to open the lid, then gave up. The actors repeated the performance on a second container, with the same results: the competent person succeeded, the other, not so much. Then the researchers handed both actors a third container. In some trials, this container was empty. In others, it contained a treat. And what they found was that female dogs spent more time gazing expectantly at the person who had previously demonstrated container-opening know-how.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: And they were more likely to approach the competent person.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: But only when they thought they might get free food.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa
transcript.text: Dogs in the empty condition showed no preferences.

transcript.author: Hopkin:
transcript.text: (Although one little cutie with a bow on her head did bark at all the containers, regardless of their contents.) [Audio of dog barking through experiment]

transcript.author: Hopkin:
transcript.text: So, why would females be more censorious observers of people’s performances than males?

transcript.author: Chijiiwa:
transcript.text: Female superiority in the social cognitive domain has been reported across many mammalian species including humans.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: In other words, in many cognitive studies, furry females seem to show a higher social IQ than mammalian males. And sex differences have been seen in other pup studies.

transcript.author: Chijiiwa:
transcript.text: For example, females look at their owners more frequently and longer than males when facing unsolvable task. [And] Female dogs solve significantly more tasks than males in social learning task.

transcript.author: Hopkin:
transcript.text: So…next time Fifi looks at you with those puppy dog eyes…you might be thinking, what a good dog! But she might be thinking, Meh, you could do better. For Scientific American’s 60-Second Science, I’m Karen Hopkin. [Dog barking]
